DataElement.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor AJCC Edition 8 Clinical Tumor T Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the primary colon and rectal neuroendocrine tumor based on information obtained from the date of cancer diagnosis until the start of definitive treatment, or within four months (whichever is shorter), using AJCC Ed. 8 criteria.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor Clinical T Category
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A well differentiated, low or intermediate grade tumor with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the colon or rectum._Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity._One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A well differentiated, low or intermediate grade tumor with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the colon or rectum.

Concepts.definition: A well differentiated, low, intermediate, or high grade neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the colon or rectum.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: AJCC Based:Staging Criteria Based on American Joint Committee on Cancer System

ValueDomain.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 8 T Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of a colorectal neuroendocrine tumor, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. This classification system applies to colorectal "carcinoid" tumors (neuroendocrine tumor G1 and G2, and rare-well differentiated G3). It does not apply to high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas and mixed adenoneuroendocrine carcinomas of the colon and rectum. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion)._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pTX TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pTX TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pTX TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT4 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT4 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading the visceral peritoneum (serosa) or other organs or adjacent structures. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT4 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading the visceral peritoneum (serosa) or other organs or adjacent structures. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT3 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT3 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading through the muscularis propria into subserosal tissue without penetration of overlying serosa. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT3 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading through the muscularis propria into subserosal tissue without penetration of overlying serosa. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT2 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT2 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading the muscularis propria or measuring more than 2 cm with invasion of the lamina propria or submucosa.  (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT2 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading the muscularis propria or measuring more than 2 cm with invasion of the lamina propria or submucosa.  (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1b TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1b TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor measuring 1-2 cm in greatest dimension. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1b TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor measuring 1-2 cm in greatest dimension. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1a TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1a TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor measuring less than 1 cm in greatest dimension. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1a TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor measuring less than 1 cm in greatest dimension. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading the lamina propria or submucosa and measuring 2 cm or less. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT1 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor invading the lamina propria or submucosa and measuring 2 cm or less. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT0 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT0 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor pT0 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumor with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

It does not apply to high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas and mixed adenoneuroendocrine carcinomas of the colon and rectum. Concepts.longName: Colorectal Neuroendocrine Tumor TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: A finding about one or more characteristics of a colorectal neuroendocrine tumor, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. This classification system applies to colorectal "carcinoid" tumors (neuroendocrine tumor G1 and G2, and rare-well differentiated G3). It does not apply to high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas and mixed adenoneuroendocrine carcinomas of the colon and rectum. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
